title: Saturday Kitchen viewers angry at Nieves Barragan 'scaring' an octopus | Metro News
text:
Hannah Lawrence for Metro.co.uk Saturday 11 Feb 2017 5:28 pm To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
TV viewers have expressed their disgust over scenes of an octopus being cooked on Saturday Kitchen. Sponsored 13 realities of going wedding dress shopping 
The 90-minute long programme has been caught in a wave of controversies today. 
Those who weren’t outraged by chef Anna Haugh’s raw chicken and cross-contamination issues were instead not happy about seeing a whole octopus being boiled. Distressing scenes (Picture: BBC) 
Chef Nieves Barragan cooked her recipe for Gallacian octopus which involved ‘scaring’ the animal, a process where the mollusk is tenderised by being dipped in boiling water. 
Presenter Matt Tebbutt made a point of reassuring viewers that the octopus was not alive during the process. 
But fans were not satisfied and many took to Twitter to broadcast their disagreement: A beautiful octopus butched live on bbc1 10am 😲 #SaturdayKitchen 
— Rob Walker (@robwalker909) February 11, 2017 #SaturdayKitchenpoor old octopus! Worse thing I've ever seen on Saturday kitchen! 
— Sian Morgan-Lloyd (@SianMorganLloy3) February 11, 2017 @SaturdayKitchen just been watching saturday kitchen was horrified that they have just put a live octopus in boiling water on live tv. 
— Shirley Durance (@sellbynow) February 11, 2017 #SaturdayKitchen WHY dip such an HUGE octopus in boiling water just to use a couple of the ends of its tentacles??? Is this a joke ??? #BBC 
— Syed Abdul Razak (@tweetfeelsgood) February 11, 2017 
Some took a stand against the programme not for animal rights reasons but for being out of touch with every day cooks: #SaturdayKitchen gets more pretentious every week. Who in the U.K. Is going to cook octopus 🐙 
— Paul Kirk (@PaulBKirk) February 11, 2017 Used to be much more homely. Who is going to cook that octopus 🐙 dish? Looked vile anyway. #saturdaykitchen 
And for others it was just vomit territory: When the chef dunked that massive octopus in the pan #SaturdayKitchen pic.twitter.com/w7US1imCir 
— ✨🌜ash🌛✨ (@ashlienicolee) February 11, 2017 
For a light-hearted morning cooking show Saturday Kitchen has had its fair share of controversial moments. 
From Will Young being blasted for swearing on the show in 2015 to Jamie Oliver being criticised for his innuendos in 2016 the show has often prompted a reaction. 
The BBC have been contacted for comment.
